question.title: Confused about compileSdk vs minSdK: How is it possible, that it runs on very old devices?
question.body:
android {
    compileSdk = 35

    defaultConfig {
        minSdk = 24
        /* ... */
}

How is it possible that I can use modern SDK 35-features and the app works on an old device from eight years ago?

The device can't know that features. How is this downwards compatibility accomplished?

Or I'm I generally wrong in my thinking somehow?

answers.body: Well... The SDK includes software features and innovations. Then, a compiler turns it into machine code for a certain processor (hardware) architecture. As long as the architecture is compatible the compiler should generally generate machine code that can be executable on an older but compatible processor. Then, the minSdk is a limit that you define that pertains to the software and not the hardware (processor).

Whenever you write Android code, you're prompted to place SDK version checks in case you're using any API that won't work on a certain SDK version that lies between your compile SDK and min SDK. This ensures that even when you're running an app on old devices, programmatically we don't call APIs that might not exist on that specific SDK version. In case you don't use such checks it can cause your app to crash.
As an example consider the following:

if (Build.VERSION.SDK_INT >= Build.VERSION_CODES.UPSIDE_DOWN_CAKE) {
    // This API (e.g., predictive back) is only available on Android 14+
    window.setOnBackInvokedDispatcher { /* ... */ }
} else {
    // Use legacy back press logic
    onBackPressedDispatcher.addCallback(this) { /* ... */ }
}

79683591.body: By default most apps are not compiled to "machine code" because the app is mostly written in Java/Kotlin which is compiled to Java Dex bytes code. The evolution of Dex byte code is very slow so there are not many changes. But even more important is not using API methods that are not available on older devices.

Hmm... Android is now pretty mature and there tend to be fewer radical, compatibility breaking changes with every new version. So I would say that "what determines how far one can go back" are the presence of compatibility breaking changes between your targetSDK and minSDK. Usually when you adjust your minSDK lower and compile your app, you'll get a lot of warnings or errors regarding incompatible code that you must downgrade for the project to compile. The newer compiler "knows" the limitations of the older versions.

But why is the minSdk configuration needed at all, when only a compatible processor is necessary? Why then only back to 24? Why not further back or leaving the minSdk limit completely? What determines how far one can go back?
